question.body: If a protein has a quaternary structure, that means it:

multiple_choice.choice: Uses all 20 amino acids in its composition
Is most likely coded for by multiple genes

response.feedback: Incorrect. Although it is likely that a protein will contain most or all of the amino acids, it is not a necessity.

Correct. Quaternary structure indicates multiple amino acid chains combining into a single, larger protein. Each amino acid chain is typically coded by a separate gene. For example, hemoglobin is made of alpha chains and beta chains, which are coded by separate genes.
Incorrect. In fact, more proteins with quaternary structure are large, although this is not a necessity.
Incorrect. Many proteins with quaternary structure are not enzymes, but function as transport proteins, etc.

part.hint: Quaternary means “fourth in rank order” and indicates the most complex version of proteins.

question.body: Different cell types express different types and concentrations of proteins. You would expect a cell common to connective tissues like ligaments and tendons to produce an abundance of proteins with which of the following functions?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Some connective tissue does contain an abundance of immune cells the produce immune proteins, but that would not be the case for tendons or ligaments.
Incorrect. Although all cells produce enzymatic proteins, you would not expect a connective tissue cell in ligaments and tendons to produce more of these than the typical cell.
Correct. Tendons and ligaments are structural connective tissues. The mast cells of these tissues produce and secrete many structural proteins that maintain the strength of these tissues.

Incorrect. Although all cells produce some proteins that are involved in cell signaling, you would not expect a connective tissue cell in ligaments and tendons to produce more of these than the typical cell.

part.hint: Ligaments connect bone to bone and tendons connect muscle to bone to maintain structural support.
